medical_history.chief_complaint: Mr. A presents with a history of psychiatric symptoms, including a diagnosis of schizophrenia and previous psychotic episodes.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: Mr. A experienced his first psychotic episode at age 17, which led to a hospitalization for 6 weeks. After treatment with haloperidol, he showed significant symptom reduction but later transitioned to risperidone due to extrapyramidal side effects. Since then, he has experienced periods of increased psychotic symptoms that were controlled with dosage adjustments of risperidone. The duration of symptoms spans several years since his first episode.
medical_history.past_medical_history: Prior to his psychiatric diagnoses, Mr. A exhibited below-average academic performance and was suggested to have attention deficit hyperactivity disorder during elementary school, although this was never formally evaluated. Neuropsychological testing indicated significant impairments in attention and working memory.
medical_history.family_history: Mr. A's mother has a history of intermittent nonaffective psychotic episodes that were never formally evaluated or treated. The family noted a resemblance between Mr. A and his mother in both psychiatric symptoms and physical appearance. Additionally, his mother mentioned a younger sister who was described as 'a little odd.'
medical_history.social_history: Mr. A, a 22-year-old man, lives with his parents and works in their convenience store. He has been in a romantic relationship for the past 2 years with a woman who lives independently nearby.
